title: 103_hr364
content: The Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993 amends the Small Business Act by adding conditions for credit and reasonable rates. It also includes provisions for a loan program to ensure all qualified applicants are granted loans. Congressional Finding and Declaration of Policy is also addressed. The Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993 aims to address marketing conditions detrimental to businesses in the livestock and meat food products industry. Congress finds that these conditions hinder a free and competitive environment necessary for business health and efficiency. The Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993 aims to eliminate unfair competition and obstacles in commerce related to livestock and meat food products. Congress intends to regulate commerce to correct these conditions promptly. The Act aims to eliminate unfair competition and obstacles in commerce related to livestock and meat food products. It defines key terms such as "Commerce," "Livestock," and "Meat food products." The Act defines key terms related to livestock and meat products, including "Meat food products," "Meatpacker," "Meat marketer," and "Person." The Act defines key terms related to livestock and meat products, including "Meat food products," "Meatpacker," "Meat marketer," and "Person." A "Person" is defined as individuals, partnerships, associations, corporations, legal representatives, joint stock companies, trustees, receivers in bankruptcy and reorganization, common-law trusts, or any organized group. A "Meatpacker or meat marketer engaged in commerce" refers to those involved in the production, processing, manufacturing, or distribution of meat food products for commerce. The Act prohibits meatpackers engaged in commerce from slaughtering at any one location if their annual gross sales exceed $250,000. The Act prohibits meatpackers from slaughtering more than a certain number of animals per week if they or any related entities own or control a significant percentage of the stock, voting power, or control of the meatpacker. It is unlawful for meatpackers to offer for sale or purchase more than a specified number of live cattle, swine, or sheep per week if they or related entities own or control over 5% of the stock, voting power, or control. The prohibition applies to livestock owned by meatpackers or meat marketers who own or control more than 5% of the voting power or control, or by their subsidiaries or affiliates. It is unlawful for meatpackers or meat marketers to contract for the forward delivery of livestock if the contract allows them to control the delivery directly or indirectly. This does not prohibit them from trading commodity futures on designated contract markets. Any violation of the provision prohibiting meatpackers or meat marketers from controlling the delivery of livestock in forward contracts may result in fines up to $50,000 or a specified amount per head of slaughtered or contracted livestock. Corporate violations are also subject to penalties. A violation of the Act may result in fines up to $50,000 or a specified amount per head of livestock. Corporate violations are also subject to penalties. Violations occurring in more than one week are considered separate violations for each week. The Act, approved in 1914, is considered an antitrust law. If any provision of the Act is deemed invalid, it will not affect the validity of the rest of the Act.
